ESTIMATES CONTAINING VOTE ON ACCOUNT FOR PART OF

YEAR 1963 AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES FOR 1963



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



2.32 p.m.

    The Chairman: Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of the Estimates?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I so signify.

    The Chairman: Estimates containing a Vote on Account for expenditure for part of the year 1963 of the State of Singapore (Cmd. 39 of 1961). Dealing now with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper -

    Head 1 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance in his statement to this House on 4th December explained why he considered it necessary and desirable that the 1963 Vote on Account had to be taken at an early stage. I would like to quote from a transcript of his speech. The P.A.P. Government are fond of saying that they always say what they mean, and they mean what they say. If you remem ber. Sir, a ministerial statement made during the course of the debate here on the boycott in Chinese middle schools was found to be a mis-statement. In order that there can be no doubt in the minds of the Opposition that he has made a mis-statement, I would like the

Column: 2412

Minister to say whether the transcript of his speech is correct. I quote from page 37 [of the "first copy" of the Hansard]. He said:

    'The vote on account is asked in respect of annually recurrent expenditure. Such expenditure is incurred in regular amounts each month being payments for salaries of staff, regular services used by the Government such as water, light, electricity, stationery, telephone, rents of offices and so forth.'

May I, Sir, before I proceed with the many amendments that stand in my name, ask the Minister whether he meant what he said and said what he meant when these words were said by him?

    The Chairman: Order. I do not think the Member has even moved the amendment standing in his name.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I am sorry, Sir. I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $100.

I mean to say what I have said just now after moving this amendment.

    The Chairman: The point the Chair wishes to make is that all remarks must be related to Head 1, because the hon. Member did have an opportunity of debating the statement made by the Minister for Finance. The House was given an opportunity of saying whether or not they wished the Minister to move, "That the House do now adjourn," to enable a debate to be held on the statement. But that opportunity was not taken. Therefore, there cannot be a general debate on the statement of the Minister. If, of course, the remarks can be related to any particular Head which indicate that the Minister went wrong in his statement, then that will be in order.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: With respect, Sir, I am not debating the Minister's statement. What I am seeking is information-whether the transcript of what he said on 4th December is correct, in view of the fact that one Minister's previous statement had been found to be a mis-statement.

Column: 2413



    The Chairman: The Member must indicate how that question relates to Head 1. I think that is the point I am trying to make.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Because I can prove that if it is a correct transcript, then the Vote on Account does not bear out the statement of the Minister for Finance.

    The Chairman: I think the Membet should now indicate how that is so.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I would like tt, indicate that the Minister asked in his statement for a 55 per cent vote oh account in respect of Personal Emolu ments and Other Charges Annually Recurrent. That is what he meant by annually recurrent expenditure. But I want to prove that no work has been done at all in the compilation of these Estimates before us. What is presented to this House is that it is 55 per cent of the total votes in 1962 including Other Charges Special Expenditure, and the Minister, of course, cannot say that the Special Expenditure for 1962 will also be the same Special Expenditure for 1963.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did make a statement and I think the transcript is a correct representation of what I said. Perhaps it lacked precision because I did not convey the full meaning of what items would, in fact, be sought under the vote on account.

    The point I intended to make in that statement was that it is the ordinary Estimates which would come under the procedure applicable to the vote on account, because, apart fiom O.C.S.E. items which form a small part of the total sum in the ordinary Estimates, the others cover fairly regular amounts. I made that statement in order to compare the procedure for estimating expenditure in the ordinary Estimates with the difficulties in forecasting expenditure in the Development Estimates - that they are two different things. If the Member for Cairnhill will refer to the whole text of my statement, he will find that I developed the reasons why, in respect

Column: 2414

of the Development Estimates, it is not possible to ask for approval for part of the year. That was the point I was making, not that I intended to pull a fast one over the Member for Cairnhill or any other Member. I was just developing the theme of the two approaches when asking for a vote on account. I hope I have made myself clear.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): On a point of clarification, if the Chair might assist us. In view of the Minister's indication that the statement was not quite precise in character and since we have now received the full details, is there no procedure whereby we can, in fact, debate the principal issue whether there should be a Vote on Account and Development Estimates for 1963?

    The Chairman: The hon. Member is too late on that issue. I did indicate earlier on that the time to do that was when the Minister offered to adjourn the House, but that offer was not taken ad vantage of. That was the time to debate whether or not there should have been a Vote on Account. At the moment, we are presented with this Vote on Account and no details of it have been given, quite correctly. The only idea of a vote on ac count is, as indicated in the Constitution, to provide for expenditure for a part of the year and details need not be given. I do not know why the Minister chose to say 55 per cent. This is the procedure in every Parliament, that if a vote on account is asked for, a lump sum is asked for and they simply say, "We want this lump sum for X months." That is all.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, when we listened to the statement of the Minister for Finance on 4th December, we took it to mean that what he was asking the House for was just 55 per cent of annually recurrent expenditure. Those are the words he used. Because of that, we were led into a position where we thought it would not be necessary to scrutinise the Estimates in detail. This could account for the fact that so few Members of the Opposition have sent in amendments. It would now appear that what the Minister said was not what he meant to say, because the words are very

Column: 2415

clear - "55 per cent of the annually recurrent expenditure". The Minister tried to pooh-pooh the Special Expenditure as a small amount. But may I point out that for 1962, that is the basis for this present Vote on Account, the Other Charges Special Expenditure is $48 million and 55 per cent of that would come to about $27 million. We are being asked - if I may touch on the whole lot - to vote $27 million more than what is actually necessary to pay for any recurrent ex penditure. Once we give our approval to the Vote on Account, there is no control on how that money is to be spent. The only control is the amount to be spent under each Head.

2.45 p.m.

    The Vote on Account, in this particular instance, Sir, comes to about $16,000 under Head 1 for 1962. This is for three items: crockery, electric typewriter, and motor car. And 55 per cent of that vote is $9,000. Now, these three items are special items. I do not think they will be required to be purchased in 1963. We will be voting $9,000 - a blank cheque to the Government to use in any way it may think fit so long as it does not spend beyond $9,000. For all we know, this $9,000 could be used towards the payment of the creation of a new post or towards new annually recurrent charges, or for other special expenditure which, if brought to this Assembly, the Opposition might consider to be unreasonably extravagant.

    Sir, it is unfortunate that I have to speak in this strain on the Head "Yang di-Pertuan Negara", but it happens to be the very first Head. I would not like it to be misunderstood that I am raising anything against the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, but I am raising it in the strongest terms of protest against the Minister for Finance who tried to mislead this Assembly by saying something which is not borne out now by the facts of the case. Sir, I would like the Minister to note this: if this vote is given, it is clear the money could be used for a purpose which the Government considers advisable or necessary. The Minister need

Column: 2416

not have to come to the Assembly and say, "No, I think we want to buy a motor boat for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara with the $9,000." They can still buy it so long as it does not go beyond $9,000. We would have, as it were, given away our rights to criticise any expenditure so long as the amount spent does not go beyond the Vote on Account - 55 per cent of the special expenditure for 1962.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I am sorry if I misled Members of the Opposition on this point, but I assure you that if they were so misled, it was not intentional.

    The Member for Cairnhill understood my remarks to mean that we will be asking for a Vote on Account only on O.C.A.R. items. I think that was his point. If that was my intention, I would have mentioned specifically that we were only asking for a Vote on Account on O.C.A.R. items. Perhaps, as I have admitted, my presentation was lacking in precision. And if it has misled Members, then I can only express my regret. But, Sir, if you study the O.C.S.E. items, you will find that for the most part they are very necessary items of expenditure. They are items to replace various types of equipment needed in Government departments. Further, some items are really in the nature of annually recurrent, for instance, "Scholarships, Courses and Fellowships". They now appear as O.C.S.E. items. It is just not possible for us to say, "Well, we can run the Government only on O.C.A.R. expenditure." That would mean that replacement of equipment in the public services would have to be suspended. Further, some very vital items which are really in the nature of annually recurrent expenditure have been included for accounting purposes under O.C.S.E. The Member for Cairnhill quite rightly said that it would mean that the Assembly would be committed to approve of items of expenditure the details of which they do not know. I think that is a valid submission to make, and I trust he will be satisfied with two assurances which I will make before the House.

Column: 2417



    First, that we shall limit as far as possible O.C.S.E. items to replacements of equipment, very essential purchases of, say, new equipment to maintain efficiency, provision of certain items of expenditure such as scholarships to which we are in any case committed. We shall be extremely careful about introducing items such as this, i.e. getting new types of equipment which in the normal course of events would go to the Assembly for approval. That is the first assurance I make.

    The second assurance that I give to the Assembly is that we hope it will be possible to frame the Budget for 1963 if not by the end of next year, then as soon as possible after that.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, the difficulty we are faced with is this: the Minister did say in page 37 of the "first copy" of the Hansard that the Vote on Account asked for is in respect of annually recurrent expenditure. He also went on to enumerate and categorise what annually recurrent expenditure meant. He said that such expenditure is incurred in regular amounts each month, being payment of salaries to staff, regular services used by the Government such as water, light, electricity, stationery, telephone rentals, and so forth. The enumerated and categorised items, Mr Speaker, Sir, are normally items which come under annually recurrent charges. So I regret it rather puts us in a difficult position for the Minister to say now that he made a slip of the tongue.

    Sir, if one examines the 1963 Estimates, Paper Cmd. 39 of 1961, the Minister in his statement at page 1, paragraph 2, says:

    'The estimates containing a vote on account below provide for six months requirements for the public services shown under the respective Heads of expenditure for 1963. They are calculated at 55 per cent of the votable expenditure appearing in the 1962 Estimates.'

The important phrase there is "votable expenditure". Votable expenditure is set out in page 42 of the 1962 Estimates, and the vota'b'le estimate appears at the bottom of the fifth column - $352,920,900. Next to it, Mr Speaker, Sir, is "Statutory Expenditure 1962 - $41.105 million" which is not votable expenditure. And if

Column: 2418

you will be good enough to turn to page 44 where there is a further categorisation of total amounts to be spent; the first column there is "Head of Expenditure"; then "Personal Emoluments"; "Annually Recurrent"; and the "Total". On this page 44, Mr Speaker, Sir, Special Expenditure amounts to $48,150,370. It is a big sum. It is not a small sum. If the Minister says it is only a small item, it is not, because $48 million is very much more than the Statutory Expenditure which we have to incur, being $41 million. So it is an important item. Now, that is the difficulty that we in the Opposition find ourselves in - that we are being asked to vote, by the manner in which the Minister has approached this problem in asking for a 55 per cent vote, on what is known as "votable expenditure", which includes special expenditure. And special expenditure amounts to $48 million. If you will look at page 43, under the Ministry of National Development, Head 20, the special ex penditure is $6.05 million. And the special expenditure for the Minister himself [Head 32] is $32.017 million. Quite a big sum! What the Minister wants us to give him is 55 per cent of this $32 million by virtue of this Vote on Ac count,which the Opposition might not be prepared to do.

    So the position now is this. Because of the manner in which this has been presented to the House, I think it will become necessary for the Opposition to vote against all the provisions for the Heads which the Minister is asking, unless he is prepared to withdraw this Vote on Account and come back to the Assembly on a different basis. I myself, Mr Speaker, Sir, do not think that this is proper time at which this Vote on Account should be asked for. If the Minister had felt honestly that he could not have prepared his Estimates for 1963 in time, i.e. in November or December of this year, he could quite easily have presented this Vote on Account sometime next year - March or April, June or July - and the Assembly would have been prepared to look at it.

    Mr David Marshall : Hear, hear!

Column: 2419



    Mr Rajah: But the manner in which this has been brought to the Asembly leaves one in doubt, Mr Speaker, Sir, on a number of matters. After all, Sir, the only effective control the Opposition has over the Government is the Annual Estimates. The Government could govern without convening the Asembly, but by virtue of the Constitution, the Government has to come annually to the Assembly to get a vote for the following year.

    The Chairman: Order. The Member for Farrer Park is embarking on an issue which is. I think, now barred by reason of the fact that the House did not take the opportunity when it presented itself. He has made his point indirectly.

    Mr Rajah: So that is the position the Opposition finds itself in - that the Opposition is constitutionally bound to exercise control over the Government on expenditure. The position the Opposition ncw finds itself in, Sir, is that it is going to give the Government arte blanche in matters of expenditure to the end of June 1963, which the Opposition is not prepared to do.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, both the Member for Cairnhill and the Member for Farrer Park made objections on just this fact: that while they would not mind agreeing to a Vote on Account for Personal Emoluments and Other Charges Annually Recurrent, their contention is that the vote for Special Expenditure, amounting to $48 million, is a big item and carte blanche for so large an item of expenditure does not appear acceptable to them.

    May I just explain to the Members of the Opposition that of the $48 million Special Expenditure, $30 million (the biggest single item) would be a contribution to the Development Fund. You are left, therefore, with $18 million. Now of that $18 million, the biggest single item would be the Ministry of National Development - some $6 million, and nearly the whole lot of that goes to expenditure on the Work Brigade. These are, in fact, really annually recurrent expenditure. They

Column: 2420

are not something special, not something that has been sprung on the Opposition as a new item. When I use the words "annually recurrent", I was not using them in the technical sense when referring to O.C.A.R. items Therefore, the balance of Special Expenditure, after the deduction of $30 million contribution to the Development Fund and the cost of maintaining the Work Brigade, amounts to some $12, million. And six months of such expenditure would be a sum of just over $6 million. I do not think the Opposition., if they consider these facts, could say that they are giving the Government an undue measure of freedom in financial expenditure.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Rajah: I just want to answer the Minister on the two points he raised. The first point was about the $30 million which appears under Head 32, page 346 of the Estimates, subhead 34 - Allocation to Development Fund, $30 million. I do agree with the Minister that that is a big sum. We voted that sum last year too; we have voted it this year, and the Minister thinks that the Assembly will vote it next year too. In all fairness, I do not think the Minister should assume that. If, for some reason,, the Assembly comes to the conclusion that the Development Fund is not doing all it can, and there are sums left in the Development Fund, it could well be that the Assembly might not vote the $30 million. That is in reply to that.

    The other point the Minister made was in respect of the Ministry of National Development, Head 20, page 150. It is quite true that subhead 41, Work Brigade Projects, $5,890,170, is the main item. But here again, Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Assembly were to come to the conclusion that the projects envisaged for 1963 are such that the Assembly does not approve them, then the vote could easily be knocked out. But the point at the moment is this: without the Assembly knowing anything about this special expenditure, we are being asked to vote 55 per cent of $5.89 million.

Column: 2421



    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the Minister is trying to explain away his mis-statement. He is now trying to say that when he said annually recurrent expenditure, he did not mean O.C.A.R. But let us examine his statement again. He did itemise. He did give examples of what he meant by annually recurrent expenditure, such as regular amounts each month being payments for salaries of staff, regular services used by the Government, such as water, light, electricity, stationery, telephone, rents and so on and so forth. All these mean P.E. and O.C.A.R. and nothing else. I must register my very strong protest against the manner in which these estimates have been prepared. They have not been prepared in keeping with the ministerial statement. They were brought in at a time when we had been sitting for 22 days, and when every Member of the Assembly was very tired. If it had been a true statement, no one would have challenged it. But that statement has now been proved to be a misleading statement. It is now left to the Opposition to show its protest and disgust at the manner in which this has been presented by voting against every item under every Head.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    The Chairman: Time has expired. We are on the Vote on Account for 1963, Head 1, Yang di-Pertuan Negara, on the amendment moved by the Member for Cairnhill.

    Question put, "That the total sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $100."

3.15 p.m.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Chairman, the Judges are a very small body, but they are the balance wheel of our constitution. I have raised this matter before and received a most unsatisfactory reply, a reply completely lacking in imagination, suggesting that our Government intends to do nothing about a small body of extremely important people constitutionally, although they recognise that the remuneration is grossly inadequate.

Column: 2423



    Mr Speaker, Sir, I say that it is important that their status should be recognised as equivalent to Ministers. I say that being conscious that they are being grossly underpaid, we should give them justice. I do ask the Minister for Finance to give us an assurance that he will so alter their remuneration as to bring their status outside the civil service ambit. I know - and it is unfortunate that he himself has been conditioned for so long in the civil service - we can only see them in the context of the civil service pay. It is inappropriate for Judges. I say we do not have to wait until the Federation takes a decision. We should be able to take a decision now without prejudice to any schemes which the Federation may seek to impose on all Federal judges if and when the closer political relationship proposed is ultimately achieved. I do urge the Minister to recognise that this is a matter of some gravity. It should not be dealt with lackadaisically in such a cavalier fashion as it has been dealt with so far. Let us not have only sympathy. Let us have action.

    The Chairman: Will the hon. Member move?

    Mr David Marshall: I apologise. I move,

    That the total sum to he allocated for Head be reduced by $100.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, as usual the Member for Anson has over-reached himself. He has charged the Government with dealing with this subject in a lackadaisical fashion and treating Judges in a cavalier manner. What is the evidence on which he makes this accusation, Mr Speaker, Sir? I already said, in reply to his question, that Government was considering changes in the remuneration of Judges. I was not prepared to go further because at that time discussions were taking place between the Government and the Judges on these matters. For this reason, I am not in a position to make any statement on this subject.

Column: 2424



    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, he complains that I am making unfair comments and without evidence. The evidence is that the Government has been conscious for a long time of the inadequate remuneration of the Judges. The Federation has moved as far back as the 1st of June, and there have been new provisions for Federation Judges. Will the Minister tell us when we may expect action from this Government?

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have made a study of what the Federation Judges receive and what our Judges receive. The information has been very carefully tabulated and from the figures, Mr Speaker, Sir, we find that there is very little difference between what our Judges get and what the Federation Judges receive. In the case of High Court Judges in England, their salaries are more or less equated to what the permanent heads of the British civil service get, and we can say, Mr Speaker, that similar equations exist both in Singapore and the Federation of Malaya.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, I understood the Government accepted as a fact that the remuneration of the Judges was inadequate. I understood the Government accepted as a fact that it is inappropriate that the salary scales should be equated with the civil service scales. I do ask that there be some action in those circumstances.

    Head 7-

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 7 be reduced by $100.*


    *The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr David Marshall.


    Sir, this is the same matter as that which I raised under Head 1. In fact, Sir, all the amendments that I have put

Column: 2425

in are of a similar character. I have not put in amendments for every Head, because I am satisfied that the little bit extra to be voted for the other Heads will not give the Government much leeway to do what it likes. But on this Head of Prime Minister, Sir, the total for O.C.S.E. comes to $546,090. At 55 per cent, we are asked to vote about $300,000 for the Prime Minister to use as special expenditure. What do we see under special expenditure, Sir, under this Prime Minister's Head? We have here an item of two cars for replacement. There were two cars for replacement in 1961, two more cars are asked for for replacement in 1962, and the two cars cost $47,030. Then again, the furnishings .for Temasek, Kuala Lumpur, that is $30,000; Furniture and Equipment for State Guest House $5,000; and other matters into which I will not go. But this amount of $82,000, it does. I do not think this expenditure will be incurred again.
